Rio Tinto (RIO AT) - Co. CEO guides FY19 oper. cash flow to be USD 16bln at spot prices and suggested that protectionism as well as growing political tensions threatens global trade. (Newswires)

Woolworths (WOW AT) - Co. has lowered prices of more than 1000 items by as much as 50% through online sale, effectively setting up a new battleground in the supermarket wars. (AFR)

 

JAPAN

Daiichi Sankyo (4568 JT) - FDA panel voted to approve its Tenosynovial treatment for giant cell tumor but voted against its Quizartinib Acute myeloid leukemia treatment. (Newswires)

Japan Display (6740 JT) - Co. is said to consider cutting 1000 jobs which is 20% of its total workforce, while it is expected to announce structural reforms and JPY 70bln impairment from Hakusan plant. (Newswires)

Japan Post Bank (7182 JT) - Co. is to end partnership on home loans with Suruga Bank (8358 JT). (Newswires)

JFE Holdings (5411 JT) - Co. FY net JPY 163.5bln vs. Prev. JPY 97.6bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Mitsubishi Estate (8802 JT) - Co. FY net JPY 135bln vs. Prev. JPY 120bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Nissan (7201 JT) - Co. FY adjusted net JPY 319.1bln vs. Prev. JPY 746.9bln Y/Y, oper. profit JPY 318.2bln vs. Prev. JPY 574.8bln Y/Y, rev. JPY 11.6tln vs. Prev. JPY 12.0tln, Co. issues investigation report on former Chairman Ghosn and CEO says hi negative view towards full merger with Renault (RNO FP) has not changed. (Newswires)

DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

US President Trump said a trade deal with China could absolutely happen if China wants it and that his relationship with Chinese President Xi is "extraordinary", while he stated the trade dispute is a "little squabble" and the sides have very good dialogue. Furthermore, President Trump thinks the US China trade deal will end up very well and had earlier tweeted that US can make a deal with China tomorrow but added that it must be a great deal for the US or it does not make any sense, while he also stated that when the time is right we will make a deal with China and suggested that it will all happen much faster than people think. (Newswires/Twitter)

Senior administration officials said a trade deal with China isn't close and that the US could be in for a long trade war, while an official also said the differences between the two sides are so profound that, based on his read of the situation, he can't see the fight getting resolved before the end of the year. (Newswires)

China People's Daily commentary suggested US deceives itself by thinking that tariffs are benefiting it, while China Global Times Editor expects the trade conflict to last longer than many people think. (Newswires)

India has deferred the imposition of retaliatory tariffs on US products by one month until the 16th of June. (Newswires) 

 

UK/EU

UK PM May will aim to put the Withdrawal Agreement to parliament in the first week of June and said the cabinet agreed to continue talks with Labour Party, but to also bring forward the Withdrawal bill in time to receive Royal Assent before summer, while she suggested MEPs will take their seats if Commons has not approved a withdrawal bill by 30 June. (Newswires)

UK PM May will tell opposition Leader Corbyn that she intends to hold a 2nd reading vote on the Withdrawal Agreement Bill in the second week of June, whether or not a deal with Labour has been reached, setting an effective deadline to the negotiations, according to The Sun's Tom Newton Dunn. However, there were also reports that UK opposition Labour party leader Corbyn reiterated to PM May that they will not back her Brexit plan without concessions. (Twitter/Newswires)

BBC Political Editor Kuenssberg tweeted “Labour sources say ‘no chance’ Brexit bill passes in first week June - is PM trying to use terror post EU elex meltdown to get backbenchers to come onside? Or just in the business of eking the authority she has left, day by day”. (Twitter)

Cross-party talks between the UK government and Labour may collapse on Thursday, according to ITV's Peston. (Twitter) Italy Deputy PM Salvini said they are planning to introduce tax breaks on VAT for the auto-sector in the next budget. (Newswires)

  • UK ILO Unemployment Rate (Mar) 3.8% vs. Exp. 3.9% (Prev. 3.9%)
  • UK Avg Earnings (Ex-Bonus) (Mar) 3.3% vs. Exp. 3.3% (Prev. 3.4%)
  • UK Avg Wk Earnings 3M YY (Mar) 3.2% vs. Exp. 3.4% (Prev. 3.5%)

 

  • EU Industrial Production MM (Mar) -0.3% vs. Exp. -0.3% (Prev. -0.2%)
  • German ZEW Current Conditions (May) 8.2 vs. Exp. 6.0 (Prev. 5.5)
  • German ZEW Economic Sentiment (May) -2.1 vs. Exp. 5.0 (Prev. 3.1)

 

COMMODITIES

API Crude inventories (14 May) +8.6mln vs. Exp. -1.3mln (Prev. +2.8mln). (Newswires)

OPEC SecGen Barkindo said it is too early to talk about extending output cuts, while he added that the Middle East has seen enough turmoil and that stability is needed. (Newswires)

OPEC monthly report stated OPEC crude production was broadly unchanged in April at 30.03mln bpd. (Newswires)

2 Saudi Aramco oil pumping stations were attacked in the districts of Aldowdami and Afifi in Riyadh, although there was only limited damage reported and Saudi oil exports were said to continue as normal following the drone attacks. Furthermore, the Saudi cabinet said sabotage operations against oil pumping stations do not only target KSA, but the security of global oil supply and the world economy. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

US President Trump denied the recent NY Times report that US officials mulled sending as many as 120,000 troops to the Middle East if Iran were to attack US forces, while US Secretary of State Pompeo said the US does not seek war with Iran but will respond appropriately to any Iranian attacks on US interests. However, reports in Newsweek suggested the Trump Administration was preparing multiple military options for Iran, including airstrikes and setting-up ground invasion. (Newswires/Newsweek)

US National Security agencies now believe proxies sympathetic to or working for Iran may have attacked tankers near UAE rather than Iran themselves, according to a US official. (Newswires)

 

US

Fed's George (Voter, Hawk) said current low level of inflation does not demand a response and that the Fed's current patient stance is appropriate, while she does not see any arguments at the moment to justify a rate cut and suggested the Fed must keep an eye on the long run. (Newswires)

Mexico Economy Minister said the new retaliation list against US tariffs will target both economic and political elements and will take 2-3 weeks to finalize. (Newswires)

 

MARKET RECAP

Coca-Cola (KO) caught a bid after receiving an upgrade from Morgan Stanley, outperforming on the Dow on the day. Walmart (WMT), although moving higher on the day, was largely unable to benefit from news that the co would offer one day delivery across the US without a membership fee. Correspondingly, Target (TGT) moved lower. Boeing’s (BA) share price shrugged off reports that the FAA had determined senior officials at the aircraft maker did not sufficiently monitor safety assessments of 737 MAX features implicated in the crash. Facebook (FB) underperformed the market after the social media giant informed European regulators of a “serious security vulnerability” in WhatsApp, where hackers were able to inject commercial Israeli spyware to phones by using the app’s call function. General Motors (GM) was on the front foot after investors settled a bankruptcy related dispute involving JP Morgan, the US and Canadian governments. Tesla (TSLA) shares were buoyant as US President Trump administration officials stated their support for legislation that would boost electric vehicle supply chains. Ralph Lauren (RL) shares sunk, despite the apparel maker reporting earnings that beat on both the top and bottom lines. Uber (UBER) rose but was unable to recoup a meaningful portion of the prior day’s losses, and saw some negative ticks as new emerged that underwriters deployed a ‘naked short’ on concerns the IPO might be in trouble. Deere & Co (DE) was under pressure after receiving a downgrade from JP Morgan Chase, the investment bank citing “rapidly deteriorating” fundamentals in US agriculture as well as declining China demand due to tariffs and a fall in hog herds due to swine fever. S&P 500 +0.8% at 2835, NASDAQ 100 +1.1% at 7402, Dow Jones +0.8% at 25534.

Treasury yields rose by around 2bps across the curve, as risk sentiment stabilised on Tuesday, following Monday’s risk-off induced by trade war anxieties; however, the complex is yet to completely pare Monday’s rise. (It is also worth noting that, earlier in the session, the Treasury complex once again took its cue from EGBs; Italy's Deputy PM Salvini said he was “willing to break EU fiscal rules,” which added some positive ticks in the bond complex.). As on Monday, the complex saw a more risk-friendly configuration following (another batch of) optimistic comments from US President Trump, later in the US session, having previously criticised China on Twitter earlier in the day. Attention will at least focus on the US data slate for Wednesday, which includes US retail sales, industrial production, NAHB, and the Empire State manufacturing survey. At settlement, major curve spreads were flat-to-very-slightly steeper. US T-notes (M9) futures settled 3 ticks higher at 124-10+.

US MARKET WRAP 14 MAY 2019: Risk assets cautiously rebound on trade optimism
content:
* SNAPSHOT: Equities up, Dollar up, Treasuries down, Crude up.

* REAR VIEW: More Trump optimism on trade, Middle East tensions escalate further, Cross-party Brexit talks are close to collapse

* COMING UP: AU Wage Data, CH Industrial Output, Retail Sales, FR CPI, EU GDP, CA CPI, US: Fed Manufacturing, Retail Sales, Industrial Production, Capacity Utilisation, Manufacturing Output, Business Inventories, NAHB Housing Market, EIA Weekly Crude Data, ECB’s Lane, Coeure, Praet, Fed’s Quarles, Barkin, Rosengren, George

* TUESDAY’S EARNINGS: Europe; Bouygues, Credit Agricole, RWE, US; Cisco

* TRADE: In wake of the string of trade war escalations seen since the end of last week, sourced reports set the theme on Tuesday. CNN reported that trade talks between the US and China have come to a halt. Another report from Axios stated that administration officials said a trade deal with China is not close, and that the US could be in for a long trade war, whilst Politico, citing sources, reported that trade talks will continue even if USTR Lighthizer and Treasury Secretary Mnuchin do not accept an invitation to go to Beijing; the process to go to a full trade war will take at least three months. US President Trump himself again put an upbeat spin on the situation, telling reporters that the trade conflict was a "little squabble" that could be resolved if China was willing to negotiate, adding that the US was in a strong position, dialogue was "very good" with China, and China wanted to make a deal. He also mentioned that he expects to know in 3-4 weeks about any possible China trade deal. Trump's comments again injected some optimism into markets, and risk assets ticked up in the aftermath of his remarks. Elsewhere, the China’s Global Times Editor said that he expects the trade war to continue longer than people expect, and that the US is deceiving itself if it thinks the tariffs will be beneficial to it.

* FED: Fed’s Williams and George (both voters) were both initially neutral in their comments today; both said that the current Fed stance is appropriate, and the US economy is in a good place. Williams added that tariffs had given a small boost to inflation and the larger the tariffs, the larger the boost to inflation. He also suggested that, in an era of lower neutral rates, a new approach to policy will be required. George commented that low inflation does not require a response and that she is not convinced that inflation being below target does not require an offsetting overshoot, whilst also warning against rate cuts, which may fuel an asset bubble and ultimately a recession.

* GEOPOLITICAL: Tensions in the Middle East rose on Tuesday, with more attacks on Saudi Arabia, following Sunday’s attacks on its oil vessels; this time on two Saudi Aramco oil pumping stations in Riyadh. Saudi Energy Minister Al-Falih said the attacks were carried out by drones laden with explosives, with the pumping stations on the east-west pipeline, a key shipping alternative to the Strait of Hormuz which Iran oversees. While no party has taken responsibility for the attacks, Iran is seen as the prime suspect, and the US said it believes proxies sympathetic to (if not working for) Iran may have attacked the tankers on Sunday off the coast in UAE; Iran has denied any involvement in the attacks. Prior to Tuesday’s attacks, a NY Times piece suggested that the US was mulling the deployment of 120k troops to the Middle East in preparation for the scenario that Iran may attack the US (another report from Newsweek suggested the Trump Administration is preparing multiple options, including air strikes and boots on the ground); however, President Trump denied this report. However, later reports suggested that the Trump Administration is preparing multiple military options for Iran, including airstrikes and setting-up a ground invasion. Iran’s Supreme Leader Khamenei and US Secretary of State Pompeo have both since said the two nations are not seeking war with each other. However, Khamenei said that Iran will not be negotiating with the US over the nuclear deal pact (Iran is looking to bypass US restrictions by maintaining the nuclear deal with European nations). Pompeo also said that the US would respond appropriately to any Iranian attacks on US interests. Throwing some water on the flames, Iraqi PM Abdul-Mahdi said that there are indications from its neighbour and the US that the situation will end well despite the current tensions.

* BREXIT: Ministers set out details of the compromises which the government was prepared to consider in order to secure an agreement, and the Cabinet agreed to continue discussions with Labour to see what was possible. However, it was agreed that it is imperative to bring forward the withdrawal agreement bill in time for the summer parliamentary recess (how this is to be achieved remains unclear), a spokesperson for PM May said. Later, the UK government confirmed that it would hold vote on the WAB in the week starting 3 June. The shadow chancellor John McDonnell said Labour was more wary of compromise Brexit deal with UK PM May after former Foreign Minister Boris Johnson (a leading candidate to take over from PM May once she moves aside), along with Brexiteers Raab and McVey wrote a letter threatening to rip it up and overturn any agreement reached with Labour; Labour leader Corbyn has indicated that the only compromise he'd accept would involve staying in the customs union. Cross-party talks are yet to yield any meaningful progress, and PM May's spokesperson intimated that ministers were becoming more resigned to having to try to pass the Brexit legislation without Labour support; however, talks may be nearing an end: ITV’s Peston suggested that talks could collapse on Thursday. In spite of the lack of progress so far, PM May and opposition leader Corbyn met tonight for further talks; reports suggested that Corbyen was expecting May possibly to offer a Customs Union that would last until the next general election, where parties could then decide their own manifestos; May is also likely to have informed Corbyn that she intends to hold a second reading vote on the Withdrawal Agreement Bill in second week of June, whether or not a deal with Labour has been reached, setting an effective deadline to the negotiations. The Spokesperson also said the subject of UK PM May's resignation did not feature in the Cabinet talks on Tuesday, but pressure on her remains; The backbench 1922 committee's executive noted that PM May could face moves to oust her as soon as Thursday if she does not set a date for her departure. Elsewhere, the EU was cool on news that UK Brexit negotiator Robbins is heading to Brussels on Wednesday to renegotiate the political declaration; EU said it would remain on a 'Brexit break' until something changes in the UK.

* US NFIB: Optimism among small business in the US rose in April (+1.7 to 103.5, beating the Street's view). Wells Fargo said that the labour market indicators remained extremely positive, although hiring at small firms has begun to moderate. The bank also said that trade news may drag the index lower in the months ahead.

* US IMPORT PRICES: Import prices +0.2% M/M (exp. +0.7%), rising less than expected on consumer deletion, capital goods and non-petrol fuel prices. The weakness in the data prompted analysts at Goldman Sachs to modestly revise its April core PCE estimates lower (now sees 0.24% M/M and 1.62 Y/Y vs 0.25% and 1.64% previously).

* OPEC MONTHLY REPORT: OPEC crude production was broadly unchanged in April at 30.03mln bpd. Crude oil output decreased mostly in Iran, Saudi Arabia and Angola, while production increased in Iraq, Nigeria and Libya. Total world oil demand growth in 2018 is estimated at 1.41mln bpd; unchanged from the prior report. Demand for OPEC crude in 2018 is estimated at 31.6mln bpd 1.6mln bpd lower than the 2017 level. For 2019, oil demand growth is forecast at around 1.21mln bpd; unchanged from the prior report. In 2019, demand for OPEC crude is forecast at 30.6mln bpd around 1.0mln bpd lower than the estimated 2018 level. Non-OPEC oil supply growth in 2018 was revised up by 10k bpd from the previous month’s report, mainly due to an upward revision to Canada’s supply in Q4 2018. Non-OPEC oil supply growth in 2019 was revised lower by 30k bpd to average 2.14mln BPD, mainly due to lower than expected output in 1Q19 in the US, Brazil and the UK, which is partially offset by upward revisions in China.

* WTI (M9) FUTURES SETTLE USD 0.74 AT USD 61.78/BBL; BRENT (M9) FUTURES SETTLE USD 1.01 LOWER AT USD 71.24/BBL. Oil prices rebounded on Tuesday, shaking-off trade war concerns and reacting to rising tensions in the Middle East. The surge was catalysed from early reports that two Saudi Aramco oil pumping stations, on the east-west pipeline, had been attacked in Riyadh, within days of the Saudi tankers being attacked. Saudi Energy Minister Al-Falih said the attacks were a sabotage act targeted at global oil supply carried out by drones lade with explosives; Aramco temporarily shut down the east-west pipeline to assess the situation, before shortly bringing it back online. Energy analyst Anas Alhajji noted that the pipeline replaces the passage of oil through the Hormuz Strait, and as such a failure of this pipeline may increase Iran's influence of oil flow in the region. Elsewhere in supply, Russian oil flow via the Druzhba pipeline from Belarus to Poland and Germany is reportedly still suspended, following the oil contamination, with no clear indication of when normal flows will continue. In related news, a Polish Minister said he expects Russian oil supply to Poland to be restored quickly although it is hard to tell exactly how long restoration will take. Looking ahead, the API is reporting its weekly estimates of US energy inventories for the previous week, with crude, gasoline and distillates all expected to show draws in stocks: 0.8mln bbls, 0.3mln bbls, and 1mln bbls respectively. Genscape expects a build at Cushing, Oklahoma delivery hub of 1.3mln bbls; it is worth noting that the recent troubles in the Houston shipping channel will not have had an affect on this week’s inventory data due to it occurring over the weekend.

S&P 500 0.8% at 2835, NASDAQ-10 1.1% at 7402, Dow Jones 0.8% at 25534, SECTORS: Consumer Discretionary 0.9%, Consumer Staples 0.4%, Energy 1.1%, Financials 0.8%, Health Care 0.4%, Industrials 1.1%, Information Technology 1.6%, Materials 0.8%, Telecommunication Services 0.2%, Utilities -0.9%.

* STOCKS SPECIFICS: Coca-Cola (KO) caught a bid after receiving an upgrade from Morgan Stanley, outperforming on the Dow on the day. Walmart (WMT), although moving higher on the day, was largely unable to benefit from news that the co would offer one day delivery across the US without a membership fee. Correspondingly, Target (TGT) moved lower. Boeing’s (BA) share price shrugged off reports that the FAA had determined senior officials at the aircraft maker did not sufficiently monitor safety assessments of 737 MAX features implicated in the crash. Facebook (FB) underperformed the market after the social media giant informed European regulators of a “serious security vulnerability” in WhatsApp, where hackers were able to inject commercial Israeli spyware to phones by using the app’s call function. General Motors (GM) was on the front foot after investors settled a bankruptcy related dispute involving JP Morgan, the US and Canadian governments. Tesla (TSLA) shares were buoyant as US President Trump administration officials stated their support for legislation that would boost electric vehicle supply chains. Ralph Lauren (RL) shares sunk, despite the apparel maker reporting earnings that beat on both the top and bottom lines. Uber (UBER) rose but was unable to recoup a meaningful portion of the prior day’s losses, and saw some negative ticks as new emerged that underwriters deployed a ‘naked short’ on concerns the IPO might be in trouble. Deere & Co (DE) was under pressure after receiving a downgrade from JP Morgan Chase, the investment bank citing “rapidly deteriorating” fundamentals in US agriculture as well as declining China demand due to tariffs and a fall in hog herds due to swine fever.

* US T-NOTES (M9) FUTURES SETTLE 3 TICKS HIGHER AT 124-10+. Treasury yields rose by around 2bps across the curve, as risk sentiment stabilised on Tuesday, following Monday’s risk-off induced by trade war anxieties; however, the complex is yet to completely pare Monday’s rise. (It is also worth noting that, earlier in the session, the Treasury complex once again took its cue from EGBs; Italy's Deputy PM Salvini said he was “willing to break EU fiscal rules,” which added some positive ticks in the bond complex.). As on Monday, the complex saw a more risk-friendly configuration following (another batch of) optimistic comments from US President Trump, later in the US session, having previously criticised China on Twitter earlier in the day. Attention will at least focus on the US data slate for Wednesday, which includes US retail sales, industrial production, NAHB, and the Empire State manufacturing survey. At settlement, major curve spreads were flat-to-very-slightly steeper.

* FX WRAP: Yesterday’s save haven bid softened on Tuesday. JPY was unable to recoup losses after weak Japanese export figures as risk appetite returned, USDJPY ultimately consolidating back above 109.50; meanwhile XAU fell back beneath the key 1300 level, however, the key 1292 level held; CHF also traded weaker. USD gained momentum as US traders came to their desks and risk appetite returned to the market, and DXY consolidated around 97.50. Activity currencies, AUD and NZD, were generally higher across the session albeit the Aussie ended up flat going into APAC trade, other activity currencies such as NOK and SEK. EMFX performed well with CNH stable, despite the weaker fix from the PBOC overnight. EUR, conversely, was weaker, weighed by soft German sentiment data. GBP also weakened, with mixed/disappointing employment data and the prospect of an imminent collapse in cross-party Brexit talks doing little to lift sterling as cable headed back toward the 1.2900 handle.

Genscape expects a build at Cushing, Oklahoma delivery hub of 1.3mln bbls; it is worth noting that the recent troubles in the Houston shipping channel will not have had an affect on this week’s inventory data due to it occurring over the weekend.

subject: Daily FX Wrap: 1.1200 and 1.2900 levels under threat in Eur/Usd and Cable
content:
GBP/EUR

Not necessarily the biggest G10 movers on the day (at this juncture), but certainly among the headline-grabbers and both testing big figure levels/psychological support vs a broadly bid Dollar as the DXY bounces further from Monday’s post-Chinese tariff retaliation lows (very close to 97.000) and over the 30 DMA (97.403). Cable is hovering just above 1.2900 with Brexit talks between the Conservatives and Labour still grid-locked on divergent demands and UK PM May facing a date of destiny with the 1922 committee, but Eur/Gbp has eased back from peaks not far off 0.8700 and 0.8722 resistance as the single currency is undermined by more Italian political and fiscal reverberations. Indeed, Eur/Usd has retreated further from May highs (1.1265) towards 1.1200 in wake of more coalition unrest and warnings from Deputy PM Salvini that the Government will not sacrifice jobs to ensure the 3% deficit ceiling is not exceeded and/or keep debt below 130-140%. 

JPY/CHF

In contrast to yesterday when the mood was decidedly anti risk, safe-haven premium and positioning has been unwound, leaving the Yen and Franc weaker vs the Greenback and more generally. Usd/Jpy has bounced firmly within 109.15-77 parameters and looks set to close above a key technical level (109.23) after what appears a false break below and could be pivotal from a chart perspective, while Usd/Chf is close to the top of a 1.0087-51 range following soft Swiss producer and import prices. However, the Swiss unit remains firm against the single currency as the cross straddles 1.1300 and more indicative of still fragile sentiment, partly on the aforementioned Italian impulses, but also Brexit uncertainty and more sabre-rattling from President Trump and Beijing.

CAD/AUD

Both narrowly mixed vs their US counterpart as the Loonie continues to roam between 1.3487 and 1.3456 and only gleaned fleeting impetus from a spike in oil prices on another attack on Saudi sites, while the Aussie remains closer to slightly deeper 0.6935 multi-month lows vs 0.6960 recovery highs on the back of bearish NAB business sentiment overnight.

SEK/NOK/NZD

The clear outperformers, with Eur/Sek and Eur/Nok both down circa 0.5% around 10.7620 and 9.7890 respectively, as relatively firm Swedish CPI data supplemented the better risk tone and tech signals turned more bullish for the Scandi Crowns. Meanwhile, the Kiwi fared better than its antipodean peer as Nzd/Usd hovered in a 0.6562-91 band following a diversion of budget expenditure from the NZ Finance Ministry overnight.

EM

Far from zero to hero, but an encouraging session for the Turkish Lira as data and more intervention (some $5.5 bn in total since last Thursday) combined to aid the Try through the 6.0000 handle again.

OPEC monthly report: OPEC crude production was broadly unchanged in April at 30.03mln bpd
content:
Crude oil output decreased mostly in Iran, Saudi Arabia and Angola, while production increased in Iraq, Nigeria and Libya

Total world oil demand growth in 2018 is estimated at 1.41mln bpd; unchanged from the prior report. Demand for OPEC crude in 2018 is estimated at 31.6mln bpd 1.6mln bpd lower than the 2017 level

For 2019, oil demand growth is forecast at around 1.21mln bpd; unchanged from the prior report. In 2019, demand for OPEC crude is forecast at 30.6mln bpd around 1.0mln bpd lower than the estimated 2018 level

Non-OPEC oil supply growth in 2018 was revised up by 10k bpd from the previous month’s report, mainly due to an upward revision to Canada’s supply in Q4 2018

Non-OPEC oil supply growth in 2019 was revised lower by 30k bpd to average 2.14mln BPD, mainly due to lower than expected output in 1Q19 in the US, Brazil and the UK, which is partially offset by upward revisions in China

RANsquawk Daily US Equity Opening News - 14 May 19
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

DOW

Apple (AAPL), Nvidia (NVDA), Intel (INTC), Micron (MU) – Wedbush analyst Daniel Ives says that supply chain disruption for semiconductor makers could be on the cards as a result of the US’s recent proposed tariff hike extension on Chinese imports to the US. He contends that higher component costs could be passed down the tech ecosystem and soften global demand and while specifically referring to Apple (AAPL) says that the cost of making iPhones could increase 1-2%.

Coca-Cola (KO) (Consumer Staples/Beverages) has been upgraded to Overweight from Equal Weight at Morgan Stanley, where analyst Dara Mohsenian raised his price target to USD 55 from USD 52, citing the growth outlook as “clearly superior” compared to its comps in the packaged food sector.

Walmart (WMT) (Consumer Staples/Food & Staples Retailing) CEO Marc Lore announced the co. will be launching free next-day delivery across the US, without a membership fee.

NASDAQ 100

Amazon (AMZN) (Consumer Discretionary/Internet & Direct Marketing Retail) will team up with UK retailor Next to offer UK customers more spaces to pick up their deliveries. The new “counter” service will build upon the existing network of Amazon lockers where customers can click & collect their orders rather than have them delivered to their door. Elsewhere, advertising firm WPP’s annual survey said that Amazon has expanded its lead as the world most valuable retail brand, with the ecommerce giants brand value increasing 91% in the past year to USD 316bln, according to WPP.

Facebook (FB) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) has informed European regulators of a “serious security vulnerability” in its WhatsApp, FT reported that hackers were able to inject commercial Israeli spyware to phones by using the app’s call function; WhatsApp has encouraged users to update to the latest version. Elsewhere, the co. may be facing a settlement with the FTC that includes 20 years of oversight. The co. announced a settlement could come within a month.

Starbucks (SBUX) (Consumer Discretionary/Restaurants) has announced a USD 1bln sustainability bond, the proceeds of which will go towards supporting the purchase of ethically sourced coffee and the building of greener retail stores.

Take-Two (TTWO) (Communication Services/Entertainment) (USD) reports Q4 adj EPS 0.78 (exp 0.75), net bookings 0.4884bln (exp 0.5065bln), raises FY19 EPS view to 3.39-3.65 from 3.07-3.18 (exp. 4.78), cuts FY19 net bookings view to 2.5-2.6bln from 2.89-2.94bln (exp 2.95bln).

Tesla (TSLA) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobiles) – Another one of the electric automaker’s Model S’ suddenly ignited in flames in a Hong Kong parking lot, barely a month after a similar event occurred in Shanghai.

S&P 500

CVS Health (CVS) (Health Care/Health Care Services) will be involved in up to three days of hearings in June over its USD 69bln merger with Aetna, with the deal already closed but needing final legal approval.

Deere (DE) (Industrials/Machinery) has been downgraded to Underweight from Neutral at JPMorgan, where analyst Ann Duignan lowered her PT to USD 132 from USD 154, citing “rapidly deteriorating” fundamentals in US agriculture, as well as declining China demand from both tariffs and a fall in hog herds due to swine fever.

General Motors (GM) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobile Manufacturers) investors have agreed to pay USD 231mln to settle a decade long dispute over a clerical error in a USD 1.5bln loan to the automaker from JP Morgan Chase, with the settlement set to benefit those who help the US and Canadian governments who helped finance General Motors 2009 bankruptcy.

Honeywell International Inc (HON) (Industrials/Industrial Conglomerates) (USD) backs Q2 EPS view 2.05-2.10 (exp 2.08), backs FY19 EPS view 7.90-8.15 (exp 8.09).

Ralph Lauren (RL) (Consumer Discretionary/Apparel, Accessories & Luxury Goods) reports Q4 adj. EPS 1.07 (exp 0.89), revenue 1.51bln (exp 1.47bln). 

Whirlpool (WHR) (Consumer Discretionary/Household Durables) CEO Marc Bitzer has spoken positively on the Trump administration’s protectionist measures, saying they have led to increased domestic employment, WSJ reports.

OTHER

Abercrombie & Fitch (ANF) (Consumer Discretionary/Speciality Retail) announced that COO Joanne Crevoiserat is to leave after the apparel maker elected to eliminate the role.

Lyft (LYFT) (Industrials/Rail & Road) is reportedly testing car rentals for longer and further trips, as the company continues to try to differentiate itself from rival Uber (UBER).

Spotify (SPOT) (Communications Services/Entertainment) will reportedly test ‘Storyline’, its answer to Stories used by social media apps such as Snapchat (SNAP), Instagram and Facebook (FB), allowing artists to share more content with fans.

Tencent Music (TME) (Communication Services/Entertainment) reports Q1 EPS 0.11 (exp 0.10), revenue 0.855bln (exp 0.850bln), co-president Xie has resigned due to personal reasons, to be effective 6 June 19.

Vodafone (VOD) (Communication Services/Wireless Telecommunication Services) – Group revenue EUR 43.7bln (exp. EUR 45.2bln), EBITDA EUR 14.1bln (exp. 14.2bln). Co. announced a progressive dividend policy. Dividend rebased to EUR 0.09 (prev. 0.15), final dividend Board intends to maintain a progressive dividend policy. FY loss of 7.6bln primarily due to loss on disposal of Vodafone India and impairments announced in November. Q1 organic service revenue -0.6% (exp. -0.7%). Co. add that 5G will go live on 3rd July 2019.

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 14th May 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Major European indices [Euro Stoxx 50 +0.6%] are firmer as risk sentiment begins to unwind slightly after yesterday’s sell-off
  • China Global Times Editor states that China may release additional retaliatory measures; notably, China declined to comment on US Treasury holdings
  • Two Saudi Aramco oil pumping stations have been attack in Riyadh; Saudi Energy Minister states that Aramco has halted pumping in the east-west pipeline
  • In FX, the risk sentiments improvement has happened at the detriment of safe havens while high-beta currencies have strengthened
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US Import & Export Prices, OPEC Monthly Oil Market Report & Fed's George

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets were mostly lower as global risk sentiment remained pressured by the escalating US-China trade tensions, which resulted to substantial losses on Wall St. and the worst performance of the S&P 500 in more than 4 months. This followed the tit-for-tat between the world’s 2 largest economies in which China announced its retaliatory tariffs affecting over 5000 US products at a rate of between 5%-25% despite US President Trump's warnings, while the USTR office later posted details of potential duties on the approximate remaining USD 300bln of Chinese goods. ASX 200 (-0.9%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.6%) were both negative with the declines in Australia led by continued underperformance in its largest weighted financials sector and amid losses in energy names after a retreat in oil prices, while Japanese exporters felt the brunt of the recent flows into JPY. Hang Seng (-1.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.7%) were weaker with Hong Kong playing catch up on return from the extended weekend, although the mainland bourse briefly recovered as participants found some encouragement from a CNY 200bln MLF announcement, as well as comments by US President Trump who suggested we will know the result of trade talks in 3-4 weeks and that he feels talks will be very successful. Finally, 10yr JGBs were uneventful amid a similar lacklustre tone in T-note futures and as the improved results in in the 30yr JGB auction also failed to spur prices.

PBoC skipped Reverse Repo operations but announced CNY 200bln in 1yr medium-term lending facility. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8365 (Prev. 6.7954)

US President Trump said we will know in 3-4 weeks if talks with China are successful and that he feels talks will be very successful (Newswires)

USTR office posted details of tariffs on the approximate remaining USD 300bln of Chinese goods and will hold a public hearing on June 17th in which it stated that cellular phones and laptops computers are included on list that could be subject to potential tariffs, while the tariff list covers 3805 product categories of Chinese imports which would be subject to 25% tariffs. (Newswires)

China may release additional retaliatory trade measures, according to China Global Times. (Global Times)

- China has declined to comment on US Treasury holdings. (Newswires)

MSCI announced to increase weighting of China A shares in Emerging Markets, while it also included Saudi Arabia indexes and will reclassify Argentina indexes to EM. (Newswires)

 

US

Fed’s Williams (Voter, Hawkish) says that fiscal policy can improve the resilience of the economy, and that a new approach to policy is required for lower neutral rates. The Fed has seen solid economy growth in the US, and that monetary policy is currently in a good place with the Fed close to achieving their goals. Adds that the focus needs to remain on price stability & employment; balance of risks is approximately in-line with where it has been, with US data better than was expected. (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK PM May is said to be considering definitive votes on different Brexit options in an attempt to break the Brexit deadlock, while reports added she is expected to ask MPs to rank different outcomes in order of preference. (Telegraph) The report suggested that the government appears to be willing to go ahead with their plan for definitive votes regardless of support from the Labour Party.

Conservatives are reportedly preparing a new offer on a post-Brexit customs union; however, a source states that this offer has not been agreed with the Labour party. (CityAM)

Reports suggested no progress was made in cross party talks and that UK PM May is expected to face pressure in tomorrow's cabinet meeting to drop efforts for a compromise deal. (Independent) 13 of UK PM May’s former cabinet colleagues have reportedly written to PM May asking her to reject Labour leader Corbyn’s demand for a cross-party agreement to secure the Brexit deal. (Times)

UK PM May’s Europe adviser and negotiator is travelling to Brussels today to talk about how and how long it might take to change the political declaration if there were to be an agreement, according to BBC's Laura Kuenssberg. (Twitter) Subsequently, reported that the negotiatior (Olly Robbins), is not meeting the European Commission until tomorrow, Telegraph’s Crisp. (Twitter)

Riksbank's Ingves reiterates that the Bank's forecast is for the repo rate to be raised again towards the end of the year, or at the beginning of next year. (Newswires)

 

UK Avg Wk Earnings 3M YY (Mar) 3.2% vs. Exp. 3.4% (Prev. 3.5%)

- UK Avg Earnings (Ex-Bonus) (Mar) 3.3% vs. Exp. 3.3% (Prev. 3.4%)

- UK Claimant Count Unem Chng (Apr) 24.7k (Prev. 28.3k, Rev. 22.6k)

- UK ILO Unemployment Rate (Mar) 3.8% vs. Exp. 3.9% (Prev. 3.9%)

 

German ZEW Economic Sentiment (May) -2.1 vs. Exp. 5.0 (Prev. 3.1)

- German ZEW Current Conditions (May) 8.2 vs. Exp. 6.0 (Prev. 5.5)

German CPI Final MM* (Apr) 1.0% vs. Exp. 1.0% (Prev. 1.0%)

- German CPI Final YY* (Apr) 2.0% vs. Exp. 2.0% (Prev. 2.0%)

EU Industrial Production YY (Mar) -0.6% vs. Exp. -0.8% (Prev. -0.3%, Rev. -0.3%)

- EU Industrial Production MM (Mar) -0.3% vs. Exp. -0.3% (Prev. -0.2%, Rev. -0.2%)

 

Swedish CPIF YY (Apr) 2% vs. Exp. 1.9% (Prev. 1.8%)

- Swedish CPIF MM (Apr) 0.6% vs. Exp. 0.5% (Prev. 0.2%)

GEOPOLITICAL

A US defence official presented an updated military plan to the Trump administration which involves deploying 120k troops to the Middle East if Iran attacks US forces. (Newswires)

North Korea said US seizure of its ship is in direct violation of June 12 summit agreement, while it added US should return the ship immediately and that it will keep a close eye on US actions going forward. (KCNA)

Large military operation was undertaken against Saudi targets, and seven drones undertook attacks on key Saudi installations., according to Yemen's Hothi-Run television citing Military Officials. (Newswires)

 

EQUITIES

European stocks have nursed some losses from yesterday’s sell-off [Eurostoxx 50 +0.6%] in what seems to be (for now) a turn-around from the down-beat Asia-Pac session. Sectors are mostly in the green with defensive sectors underperforming, in-fitting with the “less risk off” tone in the markets.  DAX (+0.3%) marginally underperforms its peers as heavyweight Bayer (-2.7%) stumbled after the Co. lost a third trial related to claims its Roundup weed killer causes cancer and the jury awarded USD 2bln in punitive damages. Elsewhere, Renault (-2.5%) shares took a hit after its alliance partner Nissan cut operating profit forecasts whilst also slashing dividend. Sticking with autos, Volkswagen (-1.4%) shares were buoyed amid reports that the company decided to IPO Traton before the Summer break this year. Finally, as the European Q1 earnings season approaches its end, HSBC notes that from the 85% of EU companies that have reported, 55% topped estimates and the results are off the lows seen in Q4 2018 (49% beat). “Though the re-emergence of US-China trade tension remains a concern, we see limited downside to European earnings from here” says HSBC, whilst citing continuing improvement in earning revisions. Furthermore, The bank’s top-down model points to 2019 EPS growth of around 5.3%, marginally above expectations. Despite this, HSBC is underweight on Europe as US companies have outpaced its European counterparts and the “expected 2019 EPS growth forecast for Europe (c.5%) is lower than our [HSBC’s] EPS growth estimates for the US (7%) and global equities (8%)”, the bank concludes.

 

FX

USD - It’s too early to talk in terms of a turnaround Tuesday, but the risk pendulum has changed direction to the benefit of high beta currencies that were hit hard yesterday and to the detriment of safe-havens. The catalyst appears to be some respite in US-China trade anxiety as President Trump holds off on additional tariffs and remains optimistic that the 2 sides will reach an agreement down the line. The part reversal in sentiment has also helped the DXY recover some poise, albeit indirectly as a firm rebound in Usd/Jpy and Cable retreat combine to nudge the index back up from near 97.000 lows into a 97.270-390 range.

NZD/EUR/CAD - The Kiwi is leading the comeback from Monday’s depths and is hovering just under 0.6600 vs its US peer, as NZ Finance Minister Robertson pledged to reallocate Nzd1 bn budget expenditure given that Brexit and the US-China tariff spat are both compounding risks faced by the nation’s exporters. Meanwhile, the single currency is holding above 1.1200 and outperforming Sterling near 0.8700 on renewed Brexit angst, with resistance not far above the big figure at 0.8722, and the Loonie has rebounded ahead of 1.3500 into a 1.3487-57 range. Back to Eur/Usd, a decent 1.2 bn option expiries at 1.1240 may influence direction into the NY cut as the pair meanders between 1.1244-20.

JPY/CHF/GBP/AUD - As noted above, the Yen and Franc have lost their safe-haven allure, or at least some appeal, with shorts caught in Usd/Jpy as 109.00 support held and the headline pair squeezed back up to 109.77. Note, 109.50 was a double bottom and 109.23 a key Fib that was breached, but not on a closing basis and this exacerbated the snap back, along with similar tech and stop-fuelled retracements in Yen crosses, like Eur/Jpy and Aud/Jpy according to market contacts. Meanwhile, Cable finally relinquished 1.3000+ status, 100 and 200 DMAs (at 1.3011 and 1.2959 respectively) on the way down to a fresh mtd base (sub-1.2930) before paring some losses and largely shrugging off mixed UK jobs and earnings data. Similarly, the Aussie is lagging either side of 0.6950 following a downbeat NAB business sentiment survey overnight.

SEK/TRY - Some respite for the Swedish Krona and Turkish Lira on top of the less risk averse environment in general as Swedish inflation eclipsed consensus to underscore the Riksbank’s view that it is broadly in line with target, while Turkish IP fell less than expected and latest reports suggest that its planned S-400 purchase from Russia may be shelved until 2020. Eur/Sek now closer to 10.7700 vs 10.8200+ at one stage and Usd/Try nearer 6.0500 than 6.1120 at the earlier high.

Australian NAB Business Confidence (Apr) 0 vs. Exp. 1 (Prev. 0, Rev. -1). (Newswires)

Australian NAB Business Conditions (Apr) 3 (Prev. 7)

 

FIXED INCOME

Not much in the way of range extension, but the 10 year benchmarks have gradually pared losses from intraday lows of 166.31, 128.02 and 124-09 in Bunds, Gilts and US Treasuries respectively. Indeed, the core German/Eurozone bond is back within a handful of ticks from early Eurex peaks in wake of a marked deterioration in ZEW economic sentiment that more than outweighed a beat in current conditions, while its UK peer actually eked a fresh Liffe best at 128.20 (-5 ticks vs -23 ticks at one stage) following softer than forecast wage data and against the backdrop of a well received 2054 syndicated issue. Ahead, US import and export prices and Fed’s George.

 

COMMODITIES

WTI (+0.4%) and Brent (+0.7%) futures trended lower for much of the session, but have subsequently reverted into positive territory following reports that two Saudi Aramco oil pumping stations have been attacked; for reference, This pipeline replaces the passage of oil through the Hormuz Strait, and as such a failure of this pipeline may increase Iran's influence of oil flow in the region, as according to Energy Economist Anas Alhajji. Up until this Saudi update, news-flow had been light for the sector, although the OPEC Monthly report is due later today ahead of the API crude stocks report, with the headline expected to build by 2.8mln barrels. Elsewhere, Gold is relatively uneventful and holding onto most its gains just under the USD 1300/oz level, whilst copper prices are just off lows after the red metal tested USD 2.70/lb to the downside amid the heightened US-Sino trade tensions

Polish Minister expects the Russian oil supply to Poland to be restored quickly although it is hard to tell exactly how long restoration will take. (Newswires)

Two Saudi Aramco oil pumping stations have been attacked in the districts of Aldowdami and Afifi in Riyadh, limited damage has been reported., according to the State News Agency. (Newswires)

- Saudi Energy Minister states that two pumping stations for the east-west pipeline was targeted, sabotage act is targeted at global oil supply.

- Energy Minister adds that Aramco has halted pumping in the east-west pipeline, until an evaluation of the pipeline can be evaluated and they are repairing station; update on prior comments that crude and products exports are operating without disruptions

subject: Saudi oil exports are continuing as normal following the drone attacks on the two Saudi Aramco pumping stations
US President Trump defends his China tariff hike via twitter, "China buys MUCH less from us than we buy from them, by almost 500 Billion Dollars, so we are in a fantastic position."
content:
• "Make your product at home in the USA and there is no Tariff. You can also buy from a non-Tariffed country instead of China. Many companies are leaving China so that they will be more competitive for USA buyers. We are now a much bigger economy than China, and have substantially increased in size since the great 2016 Election. We are the “piggy bank” that everyone wants to raid and take advantage of. NO MORE!"
  • Click here for the tweet

subject: BofAML’s May Global Fund Manager Survey finds investors are not positioned for a trade deal breakdown
content:
• Investors are well-hedged but not positioned for a trade deal breakdown “and the full risk-off, BofAML says noting that recession risks are rising.
  • Investors’ number one risk is unsurprisingly trade wars, the survey finds (survey was taken between 3-9 May), however, BofAML notes that trade war concerns well below levels seen last summer.
  • Investors buying portfolio hedges has hit a record 34%, BofAML says, suggesting that investors were well-protected heading into the latest correction.
  • Cash balance were unchanged at 4.6%, EPS expectations rose to a 9-month high, equity allocations have dipped, although tech sector allocations are up; BofAML says that the May FMS is not showing sufficient gloom to buy (it says cash allocations need to be at 5%, along with negative profit expectations, and negative equity allocations).
  • Investors surveyed believe that 2,305 is the level that the S&P 500 would need to fall to in order to prompt Fed rate cuts; just 4% of investors believe US 10-year Treasury yield drops sub-2% over the next 12 months, 70% see a range between 2-3%, 21% see above 3%; BofAML says few investors are positioned for lower rates, in what it describes as the Fund Manager Survey’s “silver lining”.
  • Crowded trades: 1) “long US tech”, 2) “short EU stocks”, 3) “long US$“, which is why SOX -12%, FAANG -10%, EUR unch, and Bitcoin $5k to $8k past two weeks, BofAML says.
  • Investors desire for corporate deleveraging is near a record high 46%, while just 12% of those surveyed want more stock buybacks, and 34% capex; BofAML says the risk is corporate deleveraging becomes self-fulfilling, and says that credit spreads will remain the best recession indicator.
  • BofAML says investors’ longs in US stocks, EM, discretionary, tech, banks are all threatened if key technical levels cannot hold this week (e.g. SPX 2775 & IG CDX 70); and it notes that the recent EPFR flow data shows the largest day of EM equity redemptions since Jun’18 on Friday.
  • No trade deal means post-FMS investor mood has soured significantly (incoming all on HK peg breaking, bank CDS, retest Dec lows), BofAML says, and its Bull & Bear Indicator at 5.1 means little reason to “buy in May” unless 3Cs of credit, consumer, & China (trade deal) quickly surprise to upside.

14th May 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets were mostly lower as global risk sentiment remained pressured by the escalating US-China trade tensions, which resulted to substantial losses on Wall St. and the worst performance of the S&P 500 in more than 4 months. This followed the tit-for-tat between the world’s 2 largest economies in which China announced its retaliatory tariffs affecting over 5000 US products at a rate of between 5%-25% despite US President Trump's warnings, while the USTR office later posted details of potential duties on the approximate remaining USD 300bln of Chinese goods. ASX 200 (-0.9%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.6%) were both negative with the declines in Australia led by continued underperformance in its largest weighted financials sector and amid losses in energy names after a retreat in oil prices, while Japanese exporters felt the brunt of the recent flows into JPY. Hang Seng (-1.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.4%) were weaker with Hong Kong playing catch up on return from the extended weekend, although the mainland bourse briefly recovered as participants found some encouragement from a CNY 200bln MLF announcement, as well as comments by US President Trump who suggested we will know the result of trade talks in 3-4 weeks and that he feels talks will be very successful.

RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 14th May 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian indices were subdued after China’s tariff retaliation and the USTR posting details on tariffs for an additional USD 300bln; although, sentiment was aided by optimism from US President Trump
  • Cross party Brexit talks reportedly made no progress, while PM May is under pressure to abandon compromise attempts and is considering definitive votes to break the Brexit deadlock
  • Looking ahead, highlights include German CPI (F), ZEW, UK Employment Change, US Import & Export Prices, OPEC Monthly Oil Market Report, Fed's Williams & George, supply from Italy
  • Earnings: Allianz, Merck, ThyssenKrupp, Innogy, Vodafone

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets were mostly lower as global risk sentiment remained pressured by the escalating US-China trade tensions, which resulted to substantial losses on Wall St. and the worst performance of the S&P 500 in more than 4 months. This followed the tit-for-tat between the world’s 2 largest economies in which China announced its retaliatory tariffs affecting over 5000 US products at a rate of between 5%-25% despite US President Trump's warnings, while the USTR office later posted details of potential duties on the approximate remaining USD 300bln of Chinese goods. ASX 200 (-0.9%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.6%) were both negative with the declines in Australia led by continued underperformance in its largest weighted financials sector and amid losses in energy names after a retreat in oil prices, while Japanese exporters felt the brunt of the recent flows into JPY. Hang Seng (-1.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.4%) were weaker with Hong Kong playing catch up on return from the extended weekend, although the mainland bourse briefly recovered as participants found some encouragement from a CNY 200bln MLF announcement, as well as comments by US President Trump who suggested we will know the result of trade talks in 3-4 weeks and that he feels talks will be very successful. Finally, 10yr JGBs were uneventful amid a similar lacklustre tone in T-note futures and as the improved results in in the 30yr JGB auction also failed to spur prices.

PBoC skipped Reverse Repo operations but announced CNY 200bln in 1yr medium-term lending facility. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8365 (Prev. 6.7954)

US President Trump said we will know in 3-4 weeks if talks with China are successful and that he feels talks will be very successful. There were earlier comments from Trump that he has not made the decision to go ahead with tariffs on the further USD 325bln in Chinese imports and that he will be meeting with Chinese President Xi at the G20 summit which he expects to be fruitful. Furthermore, Trump had also stated that the US cannot let China take advantage of it any longer and that he expects China to retaliate against US farmers. (Newswires)

USTR office posted details of tariffs on the approximate remaining USD 300bln of Chinese goods and will hold a public hearing on June 17th in which it stated that cellular phones and laptops computers are included on list that could be subject to potential tariffs, while the tariff list covers 3805 product categories of Chinese imports which would be subject to 25% tariffs. (Newswires)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said the US is still negotiating with China and is working on when to travel to Beijing. (Newswires)

China may release additional retaliatory trade measures, according to China Global Times. (Global Times)

 

MSCI announced to increase weighting of China A shares in Emerging Markets, while it also included Saudi Arabia indexes and will reclassify Argentina indexes to EM. (Newswires)

 

UK/EU

UK PM May is said to be considering definitive votes on different Brexit options in an attempt to break the Brexit deadlock, while reports added she is expected to ask MPs to rank different outcomes in order of preference. (Telegraph) The report suggested that the government appears to be willing to go ahead with their plan for definitive votes regardless of support from the Labour Party.

Conservatives are reportedly preparing a new offer on a post-Brexit customs union; however, a source states that this offer has not been agreed with the Labour party. (CityAM)

Reports suggested no progress was made in cross party talks and that UK PM May is expected to face pressure in tomorrow's cabinet meeting to drop efforts for a compromise deal. (Independent) 13 of UK PM May’s former cabinet colleagues have reportedly written to PM May asking her to reject Labour leader Corbyn’s demand for a cross-party agreement to secure the Brexit deal. (Times)

UK PM May’s Europe adviser and negotiator is travelling to Brussels today to talk about how and how long it might take to change the political declaration if there were to be an agreement, according to BBC's Laura Kuenssberg. (Twitter)

 

FX

 

The DXY was steady overnight as it took a breather from the prior day’s volatility in which it initially fell on China’s tariff reprisal, but then bounced back after it found support within a whisker of the 97.00 level. EUR/USD partially nursed losses and GBP/USD languished firmly below 1.3000 as the latest headlines suggested no progress was made in cross party talks and that PM May is expected to face cabinet pressure to abandon attempts for a compromise agreement. Elsewhere, the escalation of trade tensions initially spurred flows into safe-haven JPY and weighed on the high-beta antipodeans, although some of the moves were pared as USD/JPY rebounded from support at 109.00 and as optimism from US President Trump provided some relief.

 

Australian NAB Business Confidence (Apr) 0 vs. Exp. 1 (Prev. 0, Rev. -1). (Newswires)

Australian NAB Business Conditions (Apr) 3 (Prev. 7)

 

COMMODITIES

 

Commodities mostly consolidated after the prior day’s rampant price action which had been due to the trade-related jitters. Nonetheless, oil prices nursed some losses overnight in which Brent and WTI crude futures reclaimed the USD 70.00/bbl and USD 61.00/bbl levels respectively amid tough US rhetoric surrounding Iran, while participants look ahead to the latest inventory updates beginning with the APIs later tonight. Elsewhere, gold prices took a well-earned breather after having notched is largest increase in 2 months and briefly reclaimed the USD 1300/oz as the China tariff retaliation spurred safe haven buying, while copper partially rebounded and as Trump’s good cop, bad cop tactics provided some solace overnight. 

GEOPOLITICS 

US President Trump said if Iran does anything it will be a big mistake. In related news, a US defence official presented an updated military plan to the Trump administration which involves deploying 120k troops to the Middle East if Iran attacks US forces. (Newswires)

North Korea said US seizure of its ship is in direct violation of June 12 summit agreement, while it added US should return the ship immediately and that it will keep a close eye on US actions going forward. (KCNA) 

US

An escalation of trade tensions has kept a bid in US Treasuries on Monday, which began on the front foot in APAC trade, and the trajectory continued after China announced its retaliatory measures after the US boosted tariffs on Friday. The short end of the curve saw yields lower by over 6bps, while the longer end saw yields down by around 3bps; the notorious 3m/10yr spread inverted again, however, at settlement, major curve spreads were a touch steeper. The buying of Treasuries once again saw the implied probability of Fed rate cuts in 2019 rise (to around 70%, according to the CME’s Fedwatch tool, from around 60% at the end of last week). The complex came off highs in late US trade following some constructive commentary from Treasury Secretary Mnuchin, as well as US President Trump suggesting that he will meet china President Xi at the G20 summit in June (while he also stated that he was yet to make a decision on whether to impose further tariffs on the remaining USD 325bln of Chinese imports. With a lack of A-list data this week, the focus will fall on the heavy slate of Fedspeak; however, initial indications suggest that FOMC policymakers will likely reiterate the message of neutral and patience as they assess the potential fallout from trade conflicts. US T-notes (M9) futures settled 14 ticks higher at 124-13+.

Fed's Kaplan (Non-Voter, Dove) said Fed's rate setting is where it should be for now and does not think the Fed should be cutting or hiking right now, while he added the best thing the Fed can do is be patient. Furthermore, Kaplan commented that the financial system is more highly leveraged than it was 10 years and that trade tensions are a threat to growth. (Newswires)

PRE-MARKET CHINA STOCK NEWS: China announces retaliatory tariffs and US later posted details of potential tariffs on remainder of USD 300bln of Chinese goods, although Trump said he feels talks will be successful
content:
Precision Tsugami (1651 HK) - Co. issues a positive profit alert in which guides FY net to increase more than 80% Y/Y. (Newswires)

Rusal (486 HK) - Co. Q1 adj. net loss USD 103mln vs. Prev. profit USD 317mln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Autos - China April passenger vehicle sales fell 14.6% Y/Y vs. Prev. -5.2%. (Newswires)

Tech - US Commerce Department is to ban 6 Chinese firms from exporting tech. (Newswires)

Trade

China announced to raise tariffs on some US goods from 1st June in which it plans to set import tariffs against over 5000 US products and are to impose tariffs ranging from 5% to 25%. Reports added that China is to carry out 25% tariffs on 2,493 items of US goods (approx. USD 60bln), 1,078 items to be subject to 20% of tariffs, 974 items subject to 10% of tariffs and 595 items continue to be levied at 5% tariffs. Furthermore, China stated they have received applications from companies to get waivers from the additional tariffs, products on the waiver list will be exempt from additional tariffs for a period of one year, while there were separate comments from the China Global Times Editor that China may stop purchasing US agricultural products and energy, reduce Boeing (BA) orders and restrict US service trade with China. (Newswires)

USTR office posted details of tariffs on remaining USD 300bln of Chinese goods and will hold a public hearing on June 17th in which it stated that cellular phones and laptops computers are included on list that could be subject to potential tariffs, while the tariff list covers 3805 product categories of Chinese imports which would be subject to 25% tariffs. (Newswires)

US President Trump said he has not made the decision to go ahead with tariffs on the further USD 325bln in Chinese imports, while he suggested that he will be meeting with Chinese President Xi at the G20 summit and expects a fruitful meeting. Furthermore, Trump commented that the US cannot let China take advantage of it any longer and there can be some retaliation in the trade dispute as he expects China to retaliate against US farmers. (Newswires)

US President Trump tweeted that there is no reason that the US consumer should pay for the Chinese tariffs that take effect today, while added that China should not retaliate or it will only get worse and warned that China will be hurt badly if it doesn’t make a deal. (Newswires)

US President Trump reiterated will know in 3-4 weeks if talks with China are successful and feels talks will be successful. (Newswires) 

MSCI - MSCI is to increase weighting of China A shares in Emerging Markets, while it also included Saudi Arabia indexes and will reclassify Argentina indexes to EM. (Newswires) 

Other News - More than 50% of Canadian companies operating in China either revised, postponed or cancelled business plans in China, according to Canada China Business Council survey. (Newswires)
